name: Riemann zeta function
rephrased: The Riemann zeta function is defined for complex numbers s with a real part greater than 1 by a specific infinite series. The famous Riemann Hypothesis, which is the core conjecture here, states that all non-trivial zeros of this function have a real part of exactly 1/2.
implication_form: If a complex number is a non-trivial zero of the Riemann zeta function, then its real part is 1/2.
explained: The Riemann zeta function, denoted by ζ(s), is a central mathematical function in complex analysis and number theory. For complex numbers s with real part greater than 1, it is defined by the absolutely convergent Dirichlet series: ζ(s) = ∑_{n=1}^∞ 1/n^s. This function can be analytically continued to the entire complex plane (except for a simple pole at s = 1). Its zeros are deeply connected to the distribution of prime numbers, and the famous Riemann Hypothesis, which remains unproven, conjectures that all non-trivial zeros lie on the critical line with real part 1/2.
related_conjectures: Gödel-Escher-Bach (a meta-mathematical work, but illustrates deep connections)
